Events.html: 362 BC – Battle of Mantinea: The Thebans, led by Epaminondas, defeated the Spartans.
Events.text: Battle of Mantinea: The Thebans, led by Epaminondas, defeated the Spartans.

Events.html: 414 – Emperor Theodosius II, age 13, yields power to his older sister Aelia Pulcheria, who reigned as regent and proclaimed herself empress (Augusta) of the Eastern Roman Empire.
Events.text: Emperor Theodosius II, age 13, yields power to his older sister Aelia Pulcheria, who reigned as regent and proclaimed herself empress (Augusta) of the Eastern Roman Empire.

Events.html: 836 – Pactum Sicardi, a peace treaty between the Principality of Benevento and the Duchy of Naples, is signed.
Events.text: Pactum Sicardi, a peace treaty between the Principality of Benevento and the Duchy of Naples, is signed.

Events.html: 993 – Ulrich of Augsburg is canonized as a saint.
Events.text: Ulrich of Augsburg is canonized as a saint.

Events.html: 1054 – A supernova is seen by Chinese, Arab and possibly Amerindian observers near the star Zeta Tauri. For several months it remains bright enough to be seen during the day. Its remnants form the Crab Nebula.
Events.text: A supernova is seen by Chinese, Arab and possibly Amerindian observers near the star Zeta Tauri. For several months it remains bright enough to be seen during the day. Its remnants form the Crab Nebula.

Events.html: 1120 – Jordan II of Capua is anointed as prince after his infant nephew's death.
Events.text: Jordan II of Capua is anointed as prince after his infant nephew's death.

Events.html: 1187 – The Crusades: Battle of Hattin: Saladin defeats Guy of Lusignan, King of Jerusalem.
Events.text: The Crusades: Battle of Hattin: Saladin defeats Guy of Lusignan, King of Jerusalem.

Events.html: 1253 – Battle of West-Capelle: John I of Avesnes defeats Guy of Dampierre.
Events.text: Battle of West-Capelle: John I of Avesnes defeats Guy of Dampierre.

Events.html: 1359 – Francesco II Ordelaffi of Forlì surrenders to the Papal commander Gil de Albornoz.
Events.text: Francesco II Ordelaffi of Forlì surrenders to the Papal commander Gil de Albornoz.

Events.html: 1456 – Ottoman wars in Europe: The Siege of Nándorfeqhérvár (Belgrade) begins.
Events.text: Ottoman wars in Europe: The Siege of Nándorfeqhérvár (Belgrade) begins.

Events.html: 1534 – Christian III is elected King of Denmark and Norway in the town of Rye.
Events.text: Christian III is elected King of Denmark and Norway in the town of Rye.

links.subject: Christian III is elected King of Denmark and Norway
links.title: Election of Christian III

Events.html: 1610 – The Battle of Klushino is fought between forces of the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth and Russia during the Polish-Muscovite War.
Events.text: The Battle of Klushino is fought between forces of the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth and Russia during the Polish-Muscovite War.

Events.html: 1634 – The city of Trois-Rivières is founded in New France (now Quebec, Canada).
Events.text: The city of Trois-Rivières is founded in New France (now Quebec, Canada).

Events.html: 1744 – The Treaty of Lancaster, in which the Iroquois cedes lands between the Allegheny Mountains and the Ohio River to the British colonies, was signed in Lancaster, Pennsylvania.
Events.text: The Treaty of Lancaster, in which the Iroquois cedes lands between the Allegheny Mountains and the Ohio River to the British colonies, was signed in Lancaster, Pennsylvania.

Events.html: 1754 – French and Indian War: George Washington surrenders Fort Necessity to French Capt. Louis Coulon de Villiers.
Events.text: French and Indian War: George Washington surrenders Fort Necessity to French Capt. Louis Coulon de Villiers.

Events.html: 1774 – Orangetown Resolutions are adopted in the Province of New York, one of many protests against the British Parliament's Coercive Acts
Events.text: Orangetown Resolutions are adopted in the Province of New York, one of many protests against the British Parliament's Coercive Acts

Events.html:
1776 – American Revolution: The United States Declaration of Independence is adopted by the Second Continental Congress.
The United States declared its independence in 1776.
Events.text:
American Revolution: The United States Declaration of Independence is adopted by the Second Continental Congress.




The United States declared its independence in 1776.

Events.html: 1778 – American Revolutionary War: American forces under George Clark capture Kaskaskia during the Illinois campaign.
Events.text: American Revolutionary War: American forces under George Clark capture Kaskaskia during the Illinois campaign.

Events.html: 1802 – At West Point, New York, the United States Military Academy opens.
Events.text: At West Point, New York, the United States Military Academy opens.

Events.html: 1803 – The Louisiana Purchase is announced to the American people.
Events.text: The Louisiana Purchase is announced to the American people.

Events.html: 1817 – In Rome, New York, construction on the Erie Canal begins.
Events.text: In Rome, New York, construction on the Erie Canal begins.

Events.html: 1826 – Thomas Jefferson, third president of the United States, dies the same day as John Adams, second president of the United States, on the fiftieth anniversary of the adoption of the United States Declaration of Independence.
Events.text: Thomas Jefferson, third president of the United States, dies the same day as John Adams, second president of the United States, on the fiftieth anniversary of the adoption of the United States Declaration of Independence.

Events.html: 1827 – Slavery is abolished in New York State.
Events.text: Slavery is abolished in New York State.

Events.html: 1831 – Samuel Francis Smith writes My Country, 'Tis of Thee for the Boston, Massachusetts July 4 festivities.
Events.text: Samuel Francis Smith writes My Country, 'Tis of Thee for the Boston, Massachusetts July 4 festivities.

Events.html: 1837 – Grand Junction Railway, the world's first long-distance railway, opens between Birmingham and Liverpool.
Events.text: Grand Junction Railway, the world's first long-distance railway, opens between Birmingham and Liverpool.

Events.html: 1838 – The Iowa Territory is organized.
Events.text: The Iowa Territory is organized.

Events.html: 1855 – In Brooklyn, New York City, the first edition of Walt Whitman's book of poems, Leaves of Grass, is published.
Events.text: In Brooklyn, New York City, the first edition of Walt Whitman's book of poems, Leaves of Grass, is published.

Events.html: 1862 – Lewis Carroll tells Alice Liddell a story that would grow into Alice's Adventures in Wonderland and its sequels.
Events.text: Lewis Carroll tells Alice Liddell a story that would grow into Alice's Adventures in Wonderland and its sequels.

Events.html: 1863 – American Civil War: Siege of Vicksburg: Vicksburg, Mississippi surrenders to Ulysses S. Grant after 47 days of siege. One hundred fifty miles up the Mississippi River, a Confederate Army was repulsed at the Battle of Helena, Arkansas.
Events.text: American Civil War: Siege of Vicksburg: Vicksburg, Mississippi surrenders to Ulysses S. Grant after 47 days of siege. One hundred fifty miles up the Mississippi River, a Confederate Army was repulsed at the Battle of Helena, Arkansas.

Events.html: 1863 – American Civil War: The Army of Northern Virginia withdrew from the battlefield after losing the Battle of Gettysburg, signalling an end to the Southern invasion of the North.
Events.text: American Civil War: The Army of Northern Virginia withdrew from the battlefield after losing the Battle of Gettysburg, signalling an end to the Southern invasion of the North.

Events.html: 1865 – Alice's Adventures in Wonderland is published.
Events.text: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland is published.

Events.html: 1878 – Thoroughbred horses Ten Broeck and Mollie McCarty run a match race, recalled in the song Molly and Tenbrooks.
Events.text: Thoroughbred horses Ten Broeck and Mollie McCarty run a match race, recalled in the song Molly and Tenbrooks.

links.subject: match race
links.title: Ten Broeck - Mollie McCarty match race

Events.html: 1879 – Anglo-Zulu War: The Zululand capital of Ulundi is captured by British troops and burned to the ground, ending the war and forcing King Cetshwayo to flee.
Events.text: Anglo-Zulu War: The Zululand capital of Ulundi is captured by British troops and burned to the ground, ending the war and forcing King Cetshwayo to flee.

Events.html: 1881 – In Alabama, the Tuskegee Institute opens.
Events.text: In Alabama, the Tuskegee Institute opens.

Events.html: 1886 – The people of France offer the Statue of Liberty to the people of the United States.
Events.text: The people of France offer the Statue of Liberty to the people of the United States.

Events.html: 1886 – The first scheduled Canadian transcontinental train arrives in Port Moody, British Columbia.
Events.text: The first scheduled Canadian transcontinental train arrives in Port Moody, British Columbia.

Events.html: 1887 – The founder of Pakistan, Quaid-i-Azam Muhammad Ali Jinnah, joins Sindh-Madrasa-tul-Islam, Karachi.
Events.text: The founder of Pakistan, Quaid-i-Azam Muhammad Ali Jinnah, joins Sindh-Madrasa-tul-Islam, Karachi.

Events.html: 1892 – Western Samoa changes the International Date Line, so that year it had 367 days, with two occurrences of Monday, July 4.
Events.text: Western Samoa changes the International Date Line, so that year it had 367 days, with two occurrences of Monday, July 4.

Events.html: 1894 – The short-lived Republic of Hawaii is proclaimed by Sanford B. Dole.
Events.text: The short-lived Republic of Hawaii is proclaimed by Sanford B. Dole.

Events.html: 1903 – Philippine–American War officially is concluded.
Events.text: Philippine–American War officially is concluded.

Events.html: 1903 – Dorothy Levitt is reported as the first English woman to compete in a 'motor race'.
Events.text: Dorothy Levitt is reported as the first English woman to compete in a 'motor race'.

Events.html: 1910 – African-American boxer Jack Johnson knocks out white boxer Jim Jeffries in a heavyweight boxing match, sparking race riots across the United States.
Events.text: African-American boxer Jack Johnson knocks out white boxer Jim Jeffries in a heavyweight boxing match, sparking race riots across the United States.

Events.html: 1911 – A massive heat wave strikes the northeastern United States, killing 380 people in eleven days and breaking temperature records in several cities.
Events.text: A massive heat wave strikes the northeastern United States, killing 380 people in eleven days and breaking temperature records in several cities.

Events.html: 1913 – President Woodrow Wilson addresses American Civil War veterans at the Great Reunion of 1913.
Events.text: President Woodrow Wilson addresses American Civil War veterans at the Great Reunion of 1913.

Events.html: 1914 – The funeral of Archduke Franz Ferdinand and his wife Sophie takes place in Vienna, six days after their assassinations in Sarajevo.
Events.text: The funeral of Archduke Franz Ferdinand and his wife Sophie takes place in Vienna, six days after their assassinations in Sarajevo.

Events.html: 1918 – Ottoman sultan Mehmed VI ascended to the throne.
Events.text: Ottoman sultan Mehmed VI ascended to the throne.

Events.html: 1918 – World War I: The Battle of Hamel, a successful attack by the Australian Corps against German positions near the town of Le Hamel on the Western Front.
Events.text: World War I: The Battle of Hamel, a successful attack by the Australian Corps against German positions near the town of Le Hamel on the Western Front.

Events.html: 1918 – Bolsheviks killed Tsar Nicholas II of Russia and his family (Julian calendar date).
Events.text: Bolsheviks killed Tsar Nicholas II of Russia and his family (Julian calendar date).

Events.html: 1926 – Knoebels Amusement Resort is opened in Elysburg, Pennsylvania.
Events.text: Knoebels Amusement Resort is opened in Elysburg, Pennsylvania.

Events.html: 1927 – The Lockheed Vega first flew.
Events.text: The Lockheed Vega first flew.

Events.html: 1934 – Leo Szilard patented the chain-reaction design for the atomic bomb.
Events.text: Leo Szilard patented the chain-reaction design for the atomic bomb.

Events.html: 1939 – Lou Gehrig, recently diagnosed with Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, informs a crowd at Yankee Stadium that he considered himself "The luckiest man on the face of the earth", then announces his retirement from major league baseball.
Events.text: Lou Gehrig, recently diagnosed with Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, informs a crowd at Yankee Stadium that he considered himself "The luckiest man on the face of the earth", then announces his retirement from major league baseball.

Events.html: 1939 – Huỳnh Phú Sổ founds Hòa Hảo Buddhism.
Events.text: Huỳnh Phú Sổ founds Hòa Hảo Buddhism.

Events.html: 1941 – Nazi troops massacre Polish scientists and writers in the captured Ukrainian city of Lviv.
Events.text: Nazi troops massacre Polish scientists and writers in the captured Ukrainian city of Lviv.

Events.html: 1941 – World War II, the Burning of the Riga synagogues: the Great Choral Synagogue in German occupied Riga was burned with 300 Jews locked in the basement.
Events.text: World War II, the Burning of the Riga synagogues: the Great Choral Synagogue in German occupied Riga was burned with 300 Jews locked in the basement.

Events.html: 1942 – World War II: the 250 day Siege of Sevastopol in the Crimea ends when the city falls to Axis forces.
Events.text: World War II: the 250 day Siege of Sevastopol in the Crimea ends when the city falls to Axis forces.

Events.html: 1943 – World War II: The Battle of Kursk, the largest full-scale battle in history and the world's largest tank battle, begins in Prokhorovka village.
Events.text: World War II: The Battle of Kursk, the largest full-scale battle in history and the world's largest tank battle, begins in Prokhorovka village.

Events.html: 1943 – World War II: In Gibraltar, a Royal Air Force B-24 Liberator bomber crashes into the sea in an apparent accident moments after takeoff, killing sixteen passengers on board; only the pilot survives.
Events.text: World War II: In Gibraltar, a Royal Air Force B-24 Liberator bomber crashes into the sea in an apparent accident moments after takeoff, killing sixteen passengers on board; only the pilot survives.

Events.html: 1946 – After 381 years of near-continuous colonial rule by various powers, the Philippines attains full independence from the United States.
Events.text: After 381 years of near-continuous colonial rule by various powers, the Philippines attains full independence from the United States.

Events.html: 1947 – The "Indian Independence Bill" is presented before the British House of Commons, proposing the independence of the Provinces of British India into two sovereign countries: India and Pakistan.
Events.text: The "Indian Independence Bill" is presented before the British House of Commons, proposing the independence of the Provinces of British India into two sovereign countries: India and Pakistan.

links.subject: British House of Commons
links.title: House of Commons of the United Kingdom

links.subject: Provinces of British India
links.title: Presidencies and provinces of British India

Events.html: 1950 – Radio Free Europe first broadcasts.
Events.text: Radio Free Europe first broadcasts.

Events.html: 1951 – A court in Czechoslovakia sentences American journalist William N. Oatis to ten years in prison on charges of espionage.
Events.text: A court in Czechoslovakia sentences American journalist William N. Oatis to ten years in prison on charges of espionage.

Events.html: 1951 – William Shockley announced the invention of the junction transistor.
Events.text: William Shockley announced the invention of the junction transistor.

Events.html: 1960 – Due to the post-Independence Day admission of Hawaii as the 50th U.S. state on August 21, 1959, the 50-star flag of the United States debuts in Philadelphia, almost ten and a half months later (see Flag Act).
Events.text: Due to the post-Independence Day admission of Hawaii as the 50th U.S. state on August 21, 1959, the 50-star flag of the United States debuts in Philadelphia, almost ten and a half months later (see Flag Act).

Events.html: 1966 – U.S. President Lyndon B. Johnson signs the Freedom of Information Act into United States law. The act went into effect the next year.
Events.text: U.S. President Lyndon B. Johnson signs the Freedom of Information Act into United States law. The act went into effect the next year.

Events.html: 1976 – Israeli commandos raid Entebbe airport in Uganda, rescuing all but four of the passengers and crew of an Air France jetliner seized by Palestinian terrorists.
Events.text: Israeli commandos raid Entebbe airport in Uganda, rescuing all but four of the passengers and crew of an Air France jetliner seized by Palestinian terrorists.

Events.html: 1977 – The George Jackson Brigade plants a bomb at the main power substation for the Washington state capitol in Olympia, in solidarity with a prison strike at the Walla Walla State Penitentiary Intensive Security Unit
Events.text: The George Jackson Brigade plants a bomb at the main power substation for the Washington state capitol in Olympia, in solidarity with a prison strike at the Walla Walla State Penitentiary Intensive Security Unit

Events.html: 1982 – Four Iranian diplomats are abducted by Lebanese militia in Lebanon.
Events.text: Four Iranian diplomats are abducted by Lebanese militia in Lebanon.

Events.html: 1987 – In France, former Gestapo chief Klaus Barbie (aka the "Butcher of Lyon") is convicted of crimes against humanity and sentenced to life imprisonment.
Events.text: In France, former Gestapo chief Klaus Barbie (aka the "Butcher of Lyon") is convicted of crimes against humanity and sentenced to life imprisonment.

Events.html: 1994 – Rwandan Genocide: Kigali, the Rwandan capital, is captured by the Rwandan Patriotic Front, ending the genocide in the city.
Events.text: Rwandan Genocide: Kigali, the Rwandan capital, is captured by the Rwandan Patriotic Front, ending the genocide in the city.

Events.html: 1997 – NASA's Pathfinder space probe lands on the surface of Mars.
Events.text: NASA's Pathfinder space probe lands on the surface of Mars.

Events.html: 1998 – Japan launches the Nozomi probe to Mars, joining the United States and Russia as a space exploring nation.
Events.text: Japan launches the Nozomi probe to Mars, joining the United States and Russia as a space exploring nation.

Events.html: 2004 – The cornerstone of the Freedom Tower is laid on the site of the World Trade Center in New York City.
Events.text: The cornerstone of the Freedom Tower is laid on the site of the World Trade Center in New York City.

Events.html: 2005 – The Deep Impact collider hits the comet Tempel 1.
Events.text: The Deep Impact collider hits the comet Tempel 1.

Events.html: 2009 – The Statue of Liberty's crown reopens to the public after eight years of closure due to security concerns following the September 11 attacks.
Events.text: The Statue of Liberty's crown reopens to the public after eight years of closure due to security concerns following the September 11 attacks.

Events.html: 2012 – The discovery of particles consistent with the Higgs boson at the Large Hadron Collider is announced at CERN.
Events.text: The discovery of particles consistent with the Higgs boson at the Large Hadron Collider is announced at CERN.

Events.html: 2013 – The Death of Hung Chung-chiu: A Republic of China Army corporal in 542nd Armour Brigade, under suspicious circumstances while serving a detention sentence in a 269th Mechanized Infantry Brigade barrack during his military enlisted service spurred allegations of military abuse. It led more than 250,000 people go on the street for the protest, which is asking for a true reason of his death from the Ministry of National Defense of the Republic of China. Although it had seriously damaged the good image of the Republic of China Armed Forces, increase the probability of a possible attack from the People's Liberation Army of the People's Republic of China, it's still a sign that Taiwan's democracy is rising.
Events.text: The Death of Hung Chung-chiu: A Republic of China Army corporal in 542nd Armour Brigade, under suspicious circumstances while serving a detention sentence in a 269th Mechanized Infantry Brigade barrack during his military enlisted service spurred allegations of military abuse. It led more than 250,000 people go on the street for the protest, which is asking for a true reason of his death from the Ministry of National Defense of the Republic of China. Although it had seriously damaged the good image of the Republic of China Armed Forces, increase the probability of a possible attack from the People's Liberation Army of the People's Republic of China, it's still a sign that Taiwan's democracy is rising.

links.title: Ministry of National Defense of the Republic of China
